content.description:
A full traverse of the boulder followed by a mantle finish! Start in the shallow crack on the east face and choose a direction. The south and west faces are very easy, and the north face is only slightly more difficult with one or two blind moves. Once you have traversed the full length of the boulder, finish by climbing vertically through the shallow crack you started on and mantling to the top. Be prepared to work through a few trees and bushes that scratch at you as you pass.

 Any number of variations for this traverse exist. Change the starting position, direction, no resting... A fun problem for the creative boulderer.
content.protection: A spotter is highly recommended for the south and north face.
content.location: The shallow crack in the middle of the boulder's east-facing side. About 4 feet to the right of the left-most (south-most) arete, and just a couple feet to the left of the More Momos.

content.description: Prepare a few curse words for this one-trick-pony of a climb. Start on the ground and find the correct heel-hook / sloper / crimp combination that allows you to liftoff to a few wonderful edges just out of reach from the ground. Once you have the edges, follow them for more straight-forward V1 - 2ish action to the top.
content.location: This problem is about in the center of the boulder. Find the obvious crack with many blocky pieces and scoot about 3 feet to the right (north) of it. You'll find a couple of crimps at your disposal with all the real good stuff just out of reach. When you start complaining to your friend that you wish your arms were just a little longer, you're in the right spot.

content.description:
Start by straddling the north-most arete (the right arete, if facing the boulder's east face) with one hand and one foot on each side. Move up a little and traverse left (south) until you've cleared a large shelf above you. With the shelf just up and to your right, climb straight up and mantle over the top (the climb's hardest move and namesake.)

The top of the shelf is off limits. No hands or feet on top of the shelf, though it'd likely make a more relaxed variant.
content.protection: One bouldering pad to protect the mantle. A second pad (or a spotter moving a pad) is nice to protect the start.
content.location: While facing the east-facing side of the boulder, this problem starts on the north-most arete (the right side.) It is the furthest north start possible on the east face.

content.description:
This problem starts on the arete on the the south side of the east face. Start with one hand wrapped around the arete and work your way up. Find a series of good hands and feet to propel yourself over the top.

 As with many problems on Lover's Fortress, the first move if one of the hardest.
content.location: On the east-facing side of the boulder, find the south-side arete (the left arete, if facing the boulder face) and take a seat.

content.description: Sometimes too many trees is a bad thing. Start on the ground with your back near a young tree. Avoiding grabbing the loose rock (cleverly disguised as one of the few phenomenal hand holds on this boulder) makes this climb marginally harder. Scramble your way up, then duck right at the last move to avoid the overhanding branches of another tree hanging over the top of the boulder.
content.protection: Single bouldering pad and a spotter
content.location: This problem is on the north-facing wall of the boulder. It start about in the center of boulder.

content.description: Could have been named "Momo's Mirror". Start sitting at the shallow crack in the middle of the boulder and use a heel hook to give you the chance to get off the ground. There are many options for starting handholds- use what works for you (so long as your butt is on the ground when you start!) Work straight up the shallow crack and finish with a mantle over the top.
content.location: The shallow crack in the middle of the boulder's east-facing side. About 4 feet to the right of the left-most (south-most) arete, and just a couple feet to the left of the (slightly easier) More Momos.

content.description: Lover's Fortress is an 8-foot buttress at the entrance to the Mini Fortress area. It is located in the tree line just before First Fortress Boulder, and has shade for the majority of the day. Being in the Mini Fortress area, not many people come by. On busy weekends, you may only see a couple people all day, if at all. Being only 8 feet tall, most climbs start directly on the ground to have any real challenge. There is an easy walk-off the back of the boulder. The ground at the base of the east side of the boulder is fairly flat.
